snippet.textDisplay: Having the filter pocket opening right over the nose may allow fibers from the filter to enter the users nostrils and mouth. Some people are using Hepa filters which, on occasion, contain fiberglass. This would be a very harmful filter to use. I am using the filtrete filter media (no fiberglass), but still plan on making the opening for the insertion of the media lower in the mask probably along the chinline.
snippet.textOriginal: Having the filter pocket opening right over the nose may allow fibers from the filter to enter the users nostrils and mouth. Some people are using Hepa filters which, on occasion, contain fiberglass. This would be a very harmful filter to use. I am using the filtrete filter media (no fiberglass), but still plan on making the opening for the insertion of the media lower in the mask probably along the chinline.

snippet.textDisplay: It is the easy mask so far to make
snippet.textOriginal: It is the easy mask so far to make

snippet.textDisplay:
Thank you so much for this video. I drew up a similar pattern for several local church groups as family unity & education projects, and one of the kids groups thought of using Easter Egg tie-dyes to individualize the masks of single or double-knit fabrics. I also include replaceable cotton balls (better than or in addition to a wire) on either side of the nose bridge to improve the comfort & fit for safety and reduce fogging for glasses or shields. I also included corner reliefs & darts/pleats as ease of fit options. Another option is to tie the ends of the (optionally elastic) cords thru the neck back (string center point), to improve the bottom fit, especially for beards. Another option is a sliding knot (actually a way to use the simple square-knot or shoe-lace knot). These make it easier to adjust the fit for yourself. They are easy to do or figure out for yourself, but too complicated to describe here.
It is also easy to make aglets for the cord by a quick dip in white glue & a roll between your fingers.

re 7:15 So you know where to put the nose wire or cotton balls, the loop is at the bottom of the mask, since it goes around your neck.
re 8:55 if you fold the wire 1/4"(or less), then 1/2" (or more), then twist each end loop into a spiral (double helix) around the 'hidden' sharp end, it is easier to guide & never gets caught or scratches.

If you can't wash your mask every day, you can reduce the microbial load with a quick rinse & ironing it dry. Despite their inefficiency as a fomite, the interior microbe load for fabric is even greater than hard surfaces, so you still need to be careful (fastidious) with your own mask.

Even after the epidemic, this mask is great for cold weather wear, especially if you insert a fitted scrub pad (instead of a filter) to warm & moisten the icy air as you breath hard from shoveling.
snippet.textOriginal:
Thank you so much for this video. I drew up a similar pattern for several local church groups as family unity & education projects, and one of the kids groups thought of using Easter Egg tie-dyes to individualize the masks of single or double-knit fabrics. I also include replaceable cotton balls (better than or in addition to a wire) on either side of the nose bridge to improve the comfort & fit for safety and reduce fogging for glasses or shields. I also included corner reliefs & darts/pleats as ease of fit options. Another option is to tie the ends of the (optionally elastic) cords thru the neck back (string center point), to improve the bottom fit, especially for beards. Another option is a sliding knot (actually a way to use the simple square-knot or shoe-lace knot). These make it easier to adjust the fit for yourself. They are easy to do or figure out for yourself, but too complicated to describe here.
It is also easy to make aglets for the cord by a quick dip in white glue & a roll between your fingers.

re 7:15 So you know where to put the nose wire or cotton balls, the loop is at the bottom of the mask, since it goes around your neck.
re 8:55 if you fold the wire 1/4"(or less), then 1/2" (or more), then twist each end loop into a spiral (double helix) around the 'hidden' sharp end, it is easier to guide & never gets caught or scratches.

If you can't wash your mask every day, you can reduce the microbial load with a quick rinse & ironing it dry. Despite their inefficiency as a fomite, the interior microbe load for fabric is even greater than hard surfaces, so you still need to be careful (fastidious) with your own mask.

Even after the epidemic, this mask is great for cold weather wear, especially if you insert a fitted scrub pad (instead of a filter) to warm & moisten the icy air as you breath hard from shoveling.

snippet.textDisplay: This is a great one to use. Instead of the clothesline that was a little bulky, I opted for the nylon paracord that is sold in 50 ft "skeins" and that worked even better! Held tighter when tying closed. I did burn the ends after tying the knot to keep it from unraveling.
snippet.textOriginal: This is a great one to use. Instead of the clothesline that was a little bulky, I opted for the nylon paracord that is sold in 50 ft "skeins" and that worked even better! Held tighter when tying closed. I did burn the ends after tying the knot to keep it from unraveling.

snippet.textDisplay:
Hey Everybody,

sewmasks4heroes.com is connecting volunteers and local health care organizations to bridge the supply and demand for fabric mask covers.

You can see which organizations near you still need masks, how many they need, where they are located, and who has already donated. You can check out organizations near you that still need help here: https://sewmasks4heroes.com/locations

OR

If you are in the health industry and your group needs masks, you can request them here: https://sewmasks4heroes.com/request-covers

Thank you!

snippet.textDisplay: I made three of these yesterday, but I added an iron layer of medium weight Pellon interfacing. The sides of the masks would NOT gather, and I couldn’t keep the mask from riding up into my eyes. I used 100% quilters cotton, but the three layers of fabric plus the Pellon didn’t work at all. The other thing I don’t like is the pocket opening for a filter to be added is right where you’d want a secure barrier, and if you are not a health care provider who has access to filters, that just leaves a hole in the mask right where you are breathing in and out. One more thing: I do appreciate the clear video and instructions, but among the many links provided, a link to printable instructions would be great. Thanks.
snippet.textOriginal: I made three of these yesterday, but I added an iron layer of medium weight Pellon interfacing. The sides of the masks would NOT gather, and I couldn’t keep the mask from riding up into my eyes. I used 100% quilters cotton, but the three layers of fabric plus the Pellon didn’t work at all. The other thing I don’t like is the pocket opening for a filter to be added is right where you’d want a secure barrier, and if you are not a health care provider who has access to filters, that just leaves a hole in the mask right where you are breathing in and out. One more thing: I do appreciate the clear video and instructions, but among the many links provided, a link to printable instructions would be great. Thanks.

snippet.textDisplay: MODIFICATION: When sewing the initial square, instead of square corners, sew a diagonal in 1/2 inches on either side. Then cut away excess fabric. Turn it rightsides out and adjust so it has a soft corner. NOW when you are enclosing the string/rope, there isn't the thick lump that is hard to sew thru.
snippet.textOriginal: MODIFICATION: When sewing the initial square, instead of square corners, sew a diagonal in 1/2 inches on either side. Then cut away excess fabric. Turn it rightsides out and adjust so it has a soft corner. NOW when you are enclosing the string/rope, there isn't the thick lump that is hard to sew thru.

snippet.textDisplay: these type masks only filter what your breathing out don't want people to get a false idea that they are protected it's very minimal. It is important to cover because people are infected and don't know it and are spreading it. Only N95 and fitted surgical masks truly filter whats being breathed in it has a metal strip along the nose to pinch and make a closed mask to skin contact. We still need to cover what we are breathing out & social distance

snippet.textDisplay:
CLOTH MASKS ARE USELESS TOWARD AIRBORNE VIRUSES, YOU NEED A FILTER. cloth masks only give a false sense of security and takes you off guard. You need at least an N95 mask. Plainly irresponsible for some media personalities and even authorities to encourage bandana cloth masks. Not all HEPA filter material are OK to use-- watch out for fiber glass material in the fabric, it can permanently damage your lungs. ​https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qiYbXsIcI7E
​2015 STUDY (updated in 2020) about cloth masks vs medical masks: "The study found that cloth mask wearers had higher rates of infection than even the standard practice control group of health workers, and the filtration provided by cloth masks was poor compared to surgical masks." https://bmjopen.bmj.com/content/5/4/e006577.responses#covid-19-shortages-of-masks-and-the-use-of-cloth-masks-as-a-last-resort
snippet.textOriginal:
CLOTH MASKS ARE USELESS TOWARD AIRBORNE VIRUSES, YOU NEED A FILTER. cloth masks only give a false sense of security and takes you off guard. You need at least an N95 mask. Plainly irresponsible for some media personalities and even authorities to encourage bandana cloth masks. Not all HEPA filter material are OK to use-- watch out for fiber glass material in the fabric, it can permanently damage your lungs. ​https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qiYbXsIcI7E
​2015 STUDY (updated in 2020) about cloth masks vs medical masks: "The study found that cloth mask wearers had higher rates of infection than even the standard practice control group of health workers, and the filtration provided by cloth masks was poor compared to surgical masks." https://bmjopen.bmj.com/content/5/4/e006577.responses#covid-19-shortages-of-masks-and-the-use-of-cloth-masks-as-a-last-resort

snippet.textDisplay: Oh and yes, why do you turn and stitch the corners down. It adds to the bulk, so is there a reason for this?

snippet.textDisplay:
Thank you for this great idea. I will try it today. For the coated gardening wire insert, I think washing will ultimately ruin it. In the other masks I've made, I sewed a tiny zigzag stitch button hole 1 cm from the top to insert the wire, leaving it hooked on the outside for removal before washing. I stitched a short encasement at the top to hold the wire into place without adding another layer of fabric. I think a removable wire will make the mask more durable. What do you think?
You health workers are our heroes, and I just want to thank you for your courage and dedication.
snippet.textOriginal:
Thank you for this great idea. I will try it today. For the coated gardening wire insert, I think washing will ultimately ruin it. In the other  masks I've made, I sewed a tiny zigzag stitch button hole 1 cm from the top to insert the wire, leaving it hooked on the outside for removal before washing. I stitched a short encasement at the top to hold the wire into place without adding another layer of fabric. I think a removable wire will make the mask more durable. What do you think?
You health workers are our heroes, and I just want to thank you for your courage and dedication.

snippet.textDisplay: I've made a handful of masks using your tutorial, but I had to make the drawstrings for them with fabric because that's what I had available.  But they totally came out so cute.  I posted them on Pinterest and linked your video.  I gave my first to the mail lady and she loved it!  She had one with elastic at the ears and said it was so uncomfortable, she was unhappy about it.  My husband still has to work when a machine breaks down and he wanted one with some flame fabric I had.  He likes it.  Many thanks!

snippet.textDisplay: Absolutely fabulous pattern!  One way to simplify it even more would be to fold the linings in half lengthwise and press, then lay them on the right side of the main fabric with folds touching, then stitch around. The pressed in cord casing edges would stabilize the opening for the filter. Thank you for providing this great tutorial. I have fabric washed and pressed and will be making these by the dozen starting tomorrow.
snippet.textOriginal: Absolutely fabulous pattern! snippet.textDisplay: Nice!  Best and simplest design so far.  I like the full, wrap around, no gaps feature.  Looks like it would accommodate glasses wearers as well.  I just ordered the 2.5 charcoal inserts.  Definitely better than surgical-style, pleated, paper masks.  I'm wondering if spraying the fabric with water repellent like that used for outdoor poly-jackets and sports-wear would better mitigate droplet penetration.  Can you believe this has happened?  Ridiculous!  You can use para-cord as well.  That is carried at most hardware stores.  Just be sure and melt the cut ends with a spark lighter so it doesn't unravel.  Knots are OK but singing the ends will look nicer.
snippet.textOriginal: Nice!  Best and simplest design so far.  I like the full, wrap around, no gaps feature.  Looks like it would accommodate glasses wearers as well.  I just ordered the 2.5 charcoal inserts.  Definitely better than surgical-style, pleated, paper masks.  I'm wondering if spraying the fabric with water repellent like that used for outdoor poly-jackets and sports-wear would better mitigate droplet penetration.  Can you believe this has happened?  Ridiculous!  You can use para-cord as well.  That is carried at most hardware stores.  Just be sure and melt the cut ends with a spark lighter so it doesn't unravel.  Knots are OK but singing the ends will look nicer.

snippet.textDisplay: Too bad I can't post a photo...just finished making my first. I tried using different materials as ties...round elastics, three-ply crocheted cotton yarn (takes quite a bit yarn for the required length but I think two-ply might work as well) and T-shirt ribbing. I must say I prefer the elastics. I find this style has a good design for preventing gaping on the sides but because we are drawing the sides tight, this mask has a tighter fit that is lies very close to your face. THANK YOU!
snippet.textOriginal: Too bad I can't post a photo...just finished making my first. I tried using different materials as ties...round elastics, three-ply crocheted cotton yarn (takes quite a bit yarn for the required length but I think two-ply might work as well) and T-shirt ribbing. I must say I prefer the elastics. I find this style has a good design for preventing gaping on the sides but because we are drawing the sides tight, this mask has a tighter fit that is lies very close to your face. THANK YOU!
